Dans cette activité, vous verrez des verbes conjugués au passé, ce temps sera traité plus spécifiquement dans le Module 11.

QUESTION.TEXT: Norwegian navigator; son of Erik the Red (discoverer of Greenland); he left Greenland and arrived on the shores of Newfoundland or Nova Scotia around 1000; he felt that he had to name this land Vinland because of the vines he saw there. {0}
Italian-born Spanish explorer; he wanted to find India; he crossed the Atlantic and found the New World, which he thought was India in 1492; he took three further trips between 1493 and 1504. {0}

Venetian explorer; he got support from England, and landed on the shores of Newfoundland, Labrador and Cape Breton in 1497; he became the first known European who landed in North America; his second voyage, in 1498, did not return home. {0}
French explorer; he sailed up the St. Lawrence River (1534-41) as far as present-day Montreal and built a fort at Cap-Rouge (near present-day Quebec City). {0}

French explorer and governor of New France; the French government sent him to Quebec in order to establish a settlement at Quebec in 1608; he traded with Aboriginal peoples and explored the Canadian interior. {0}
English explorer; he looked for the Northwest Passage in 1610 and took a crew from Hudson Bay into James Bay; after they spent the winter there, the crew revolted and set him adrift. {0}
French explorer; he was probably the first European who saw Lakes Ontario, Huron and Superior, and the first Frenchman who lived with the Aboriginal peoples. {0}

French-born explorer and fur trader; with his brother-in-law Des Groseilliers, he explored the area around Lakes Superior and Michigan; he travelled to Hudson Bay in 1668 on behalf of English merchants (the core of the Hudson's Bay Company). {0}
English explorer and navigator; he made maps of the St. Lawrence River and the coasts of Nova Scotia and Newfoundland (1759-67). {0}

Scottish-born fur trader and explorer; his father brought him to North America in 1774 and he entered a Montreal fur trading company in 1779; he explored from Lake Athabasca along the Mackenzie River to the Arctic Ocean, and later went from Fort Chipewyan to the Pacific. {0}
